introduction.p: A car traveling along a straight road is braking and its velocity is measured at several different points in time, as given in the following table. Assume that v is continuous, always decreasing, and always decreasing at a decreasing rate, as is suggested by the data.

figure.caption: Axes for plotting the data in Activity.

statement.p: Plot the given data on the set of axes provided in Figure with time on the horizontal axis and the velocity on the vertical axis.
What definite integral will give you the exact distance the car traveled on [0,1.8]?

hint.p: What are the units on v(t) \cdot \Delta t?

solution.p:
Since the velocity is always positive, the definite integral that will give the exact distance traveled by the car on the interval [0, 1.8] is
\int_0^{1.8} v(t) dt .

statement.p: Estimate the total distance traveled on [0,1.8] by computing L_3, R_3, and T_3. Which of these under-estimates the true distance traveled?

hint.p: Recall the standard rules for sums that produce L_3, R_3, T_3.

answer.p: L_3 \amp = 165.6 \text{ ft } \amp R_3 \amp = 105.6 \text{ ft } \amp T_3 \amp = 135.6 \text{ ft}. R_3 and T_3 are underestimates.

solution.p: The estimates of \int_0^{1.8} v(t) dt are L_3 \amp = 165.6 \text{ ft } \amp R_3 \amp = 105.6 \text{ ft } \amp T_3 \amp = 135.6 \text{ ft}. R_3 is an underestimate of the distance traveled since v(t) is decreasing. T_3 is an underestimate of the distance traveled since v(t) is concave down.

statement.p: Estimate the total distance traveled on [0,1.8] by computing M_3. Is this an over- or under-estimate? Why?

hint.p: Think about concavity to decide if M_3 is an over- or under-estimate.

solution.p:
Another estimate of the distance traveled is
M_3 = 143.4 \text{ ft} . This is an overestimate since v(t) is concave down.

statement.p: Using your results from (c) and (d), improve your estimate further by using Simpson's Rule.

hint.p: Recall how S_3 is a weighted average of T_3 and M_3.

statement.p: What is your best estimate of the average velocity of the car on [0,1.8]? Why? What are the units on this quantity?

hint.p: Simpson's Rule gives the best estimate for a function of consistent concavity.

answer.p: Simpson's rule gives the best approximation of the distance traveled, \int_0^{1.8} v(t) dt \approx 140.8 \text{ ft}, which leads to AV_{[0,1.8]} \approx \frac{140.8}{1.8} \approx 78.22 \text{ ft/sec}.

solution.p: Simpson's rule gives the best approximation of the distance traveled since it is a weighted average of the midpoint and trapezoid rules and uses more information about the velocity than the other methods. The units on each of the estimates, including Simpson's Rule, are "feet", since ft/sec \cdot sec = ft. Thus, the best approximation we have generated for distance traveled is \int_0^{1.8} v(t) dt \approx 140.8 \text{ ft }.
